Aug 14, 2017


rOpenSci HQ

Community Calls

Weâ€™ll have our next community call on September 13th, on rOpenSci Software Review and Onboarding.

Save the date! https://github.com/ropensci/commcalls/issues/15

We hope past authors and reviewers will attend, as well as people considering volunteering to review rOpenSci packages or people considering submitting their package for review.



Discussion forum

Recently, on our discussion forum https://discuss.ropensci.org:

  • nearPoints function availability in R plotly
  • New package idea: Public Data depository using Google BigQuery?



rOpenSci in the News

  • NumFOCUS, of which rOpenSci is a part, recently hosted a blog post by our editorial team: How rOpenSci uses Code Review to Promote Reproducible Science
  • Our community manager Stefanie Butland had two blog posts on the AAAS Trellis blog in the past week
    • Six tips for running a successful unconference
    • The Value of #welcome, part 2: How to prepare 40 new community members for an unconference



Software

New packages

  • A new package rtimicropem (v1.3) is on CRAN. rtimicropem supports the input and reproducible analysis of output files from RTI MicroPEM (personal monitoring devices for air quality data). Check out the rtimicropem vignettes to get started. Repository on GitHub

Releases

  • A new version (v0.2.2) of ropenaq is on CRAN. See the NEWS for details. Check out the ropenaq vignettes to get started. Repository on GitHub
  • A new version (v4.7.1) of plotly is on CRAN. See the NEWS for details. Check out the plotly book to get started. Repository on GitHub
  • A new version (v0.2-3) of dbhydroR is on CRAN. See the release notes for details. Check out the dbhydroR vignette to get started. Repository on GitHub
  • A new version (v1.3.0) of datapack is on CRAN. See the release notes for details. Check out the datapack vignette to get started. Repository on GitHub
  • A new version (v1.0) of magick is on CRAN. See the release notes for details. Check out the magick vignette to get started. Watch out for a blog post on this package on our blog later today. Repository on GitHub
  • A new version (v0.1.4) of crminer is on CRAN. See the release notes for details. Check out the crminer README to get started. Repository on GitHub
  • A new version (v0.0.5) of osmdata is on CRAN. See the release notes for details. Check out the osmdata vignettes to get started. Repository on GitHub
  • A new version (v0.2.0) of rdpla is on CRAN. This version switches to using our crul package for HTTP requests and gains a function to work with DPLA bulk data. See the release notes for details. Check out the rdpla vignettes to get started. Repository on GitHub



Onboarding

We accept community contributed packages via our onboarding system - a software review system, sorta like scholarly paper review, but way better. Weâ€™ll highlight new packages here that have come through this system. A huge thanks to our reviewers, who do a lot of work reviewing (see the blog post on our review system), and the authors of the packages!

If you want to be a reviewer we have a new form you can fill out, and weâ€™ll ping you when thereâ€™s a submission that fits in your area of expertise.

The following packages were recently submitted to our onboarding process:

  • bowerbird > Keep a Collection of Sparkly Data Resources
    • Author: Ben Raymond
    • Issue: ropensci/onboarding#139
    • Reviewers:
      • Miles McBain
      • Leah Wasser
  • comtradr > Interface with the United Nations Comtrade API
    • Author: Chris Muir
    • Issue: ropensci/onboarding#141
    • Reviewers: not yet assigned

We had the following two pre-submission inquiries in the past two weeks:

  • MODIStsp > Keep a Collection of Sparkly Data Resources
    • Author: Lorenzo Busetto
    • Issue: ropensci/onboarding#143
  • rperseus > Keep a Collection of Sparkly Data Resources
    • Author: David Ranzolin
    • Issue: ropensci/onboarding#144

The following two packages recently went through our onboarding process and have been approved!

  • FedData > Automate Downloading Geospatial Data Available from Several Federated Data Sources
    • Author: R. Kyle Bocinsky
    • Issue: ropensci/onboarding#13
    • Reviewers:
      • Julia Gustavsen
  • bikedata > Download and Aggregate Data from Public Hire Bicycle Systems
    • Author: Mark Padgham
    • Issue: ropensci/onboarding#116
    • Reviewers:
      • Elaine McVey
      • Bea Hernandez
  • rrricanes > Web scraper for real-time and archived advisory products for Atlantic and east Pacific hurricanes and tropical storms
    • Author: Tim Trice
    • Issue: ropensci/onboarding#118
    • Reviewers:
      • Joseph Stachelek
      • Emily Robinson



On the blog

Stefanie Butland, our community manager, wrote a post on where the rOpenSci team will be at various events over the next 5 months: Chat with the rOpenSci team at upcoming meetings.

We have two blog posts wrapping up our series of posts from #runconf17:

  • MaÃ«lle Salmon, Andrew MacDonald, Kara Woo, Carl Boettiger, and Jeff Hollister wrote a blog post titled emldown - From machine readable EML metadata to a pretty documentation website.
  • Noam Ross wrote Unconf 2017: The Roads Not Taken, a post that covers the ideas generated but not addressed in our 2017 unconference.



Use Cases

The following 5 works use/cite rOpenSci or rOpenSci software:

  • Williams, has many examples using ckanr in his book The Essentials of Data Science: Knowledge Discovery Using R 1
  • Bartomeus et al. used and cited taxize in their paper On the inconsistency of pollinator species traits for predicting either response to land-use change or functional contribution 2
  • Swani and Tyagi cite one of our blog posts (Reproducible research is still a challenge) in their paper Dockerization (Replacement of VMs) 3
  • Bosch cites and uses rgbif in his thesis Marine Species Distributions: From data to predictive models 4
  • Senderov et al. mentions rOpenSci in their paper OpenBiodiv: an Implementaion of a Semantic System Running on top of the Biodiversity Knowledge Graph 5





Submit news to rOpenSci

Reach out to us with your news suggestions by sending us an email info@ropensci.org or by contacting us on Twitter @ropensci



Keep up with rOpenSci news

There are a number of ways to keep up with what rOpenSci is doing:

  • Mailing list: Sign up with an email address to get new blog posts sent to your inbox -> ropensci.org/#subscribe
  • rOpenSci on Twitter: weâ€™re @ropensci
  • The rOpenSci blog at ropensci.org/blog - you can subscribe in any RSS aggregator, or manually via https://ropensci.org/feed.xml. We also announce new blog posts on our Twitter account.
  • rOpenSci news. XML feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.xml - JSON feed at https://news.ropensci.org//feed.json
